DOC.HEAD: No Talks in Sight for Boeing Engineers After Contract Rejection
DOC.TEXT: Boeing Co. faced a new labor threat Tuesday from the engineers and scientists who play a crucial role in designing its planes, less than a month after a crippling Machinists strike ended at the aerospace giant. In ballots counted Monday night, those members of the Seattle Professional Engineering Employees Association voted 69 percent to reject a three-year contract offer from the world's largest commercial airline builder. Although members also voted by 52 percent not to authorize their negotiators to call a strike, the union said it might be well into 1990 before the contract talks resume. ``Our executive director has been in touch with the director of labor relations at Boeing and we've made known our availability at any time,'' said Dan Mahoney, union general counsel. ``However, it appears the rejection was quite a surprise to company negotiators and they weren't prepared for it, so they have to assemble their negotiating team.'' Company negotiators apparently had made commitments to other activities and face a logistical problem in getting them all back together, Mahoney said. ``Right now, if I had to guess, it would be after the first of the year'' before negotiations will resume, Mahoney said. Boeing officials were meeting to discuss the situation, but there was no indication when talks might resume, company spokesman Paul Binder said. The engineering union's other unit, which represents Boeing technical and support workers, ratified a separate three-year pact by nearly 2 to 1. Both contracts expired Dec. 1. The offer rejected by engineers, who now make an average of nearly $40,000 a year, included a 3 percent wage increase, a productivity bonus of 10 percent of gross pay in the first year and no further general increases. Technicians, with average pay of about $28,000, accepted wage increases of up to 3 percent and bonuses of up to 10 percent. Mahoney said the union was sending a survey to its engineer members ``so when we do go to the table we'll know what to ask for.'' He added, however, that ``the engineers feel the money offer undervalued their services. I do believe they (company negotiators) will have to offer more money.'' Members of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers voted Nov. 18 to end a 48-day strike and accept a three-year pact.
